{{marriage|[[Nancy Sorrell]]|2003}} | children = 4 | website = | footnotes = }} '''James Roderick Moir''' (born 24 January 1959), better known by the [[stage name]] '''Vic Reeves''', is an English [[comedian]], [[artist]], [[actor]] and [[television presenter]], best known for his [[double act]] with [[Bob Mortimer]] (see [[Vic and Bob]]). He is known for his [[surrealism|surreal]] and [[Non sequitur (literary device)|non sequitur]] sense of humour. In 2003, Reeves and Mortimer were listed in ''[[The Observer]]'' as one of the 50 funniest acts in [[British comedy]]. In a 2005 poll to find the ''Comedians' Comedian'', Reeves and Mortimer were voted the 8th greatest comedy act ever by fellow [[comedian]]s and comedy insiders.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4141019.stm | work=BBC News | title=Cook voted 'comedians' comedian' | date=2 January 2005 | accessdate=27 May 2010}} ==Career== After school, Reeves undertook an apprenticeship in [[mechanical engineering]] at a factory in [[Newton Aycliffe]].CITATION NEEDED Eventually he moved to London. Reeves also formed the Fashionable Five, a group of five friends (including Jack Dent, who ran the original Fan Club) who would follow bands like [[the Enid]] and [[Free (band)|Free]] onto stage, and perform pranks (including Reeves pretending to have a [[brass]] hand, and following a [[Terry Scott]] lookalike around [[Darlington]] town centre in single file formation). Eventually, they formed their own band. Reeves had an early breakthrough with the help of comedian [[Malcolm Hardee]]. In 1983, Reeves began a part-time course at a local [[art college]], developed his love of [[painting]] and eventually persuaded a local [[art gallery]] to stage an [[Art exhibition|exhibition]] of his work. Although still primarily known as a [[comedian]], Reeves is gaining a reputation as an [[artist]]. His [[drawings]] and [[paintings]] have been used in his [[television shows]] and form a major part of his 1999 book, ''Sun Boiled Onions''. {{further|#Art}} ===As Vic Reeves=== As well as working and performing in bands in London, including being an original member of the Industrial/Experimental band [[Test Dept]]{{Citation |last=Wilkinson|first = Roy|title=Mojo Eyewitness; Test Dept on the frontline of the Miner's Strike, 1984|newspaper=Mojo|pages=29–30|date=October 2015|accessdate=21 August 2015}} and performing onstage with them at their debut gig (then leaving soon afterwards), Reeves also joined the [[alternative comedy]] circuit under many different guises. These included a loudmouthed American called Jim Bell, a [[beat poet]] called Mister Mystery and, eventually, "The North-East's Top [[Light Entertainment|Light Entertainer]]" – Vic Reeves. His stage show ''[[Vic Reeves Big Night Out]]'' began life as a regular Thursday night gig at Goldsmith's Tavern, [[New Cross]] (now the New Cross House). Here, he met [[Bob Mortimer]], a [[solicitor]] who attended the show and enjoyed it so much that he soon began to participate. Reeves' television début came in December 1986 on Channel 4 Television's ''[[The Tube (TV series)|The Tube]]'' in a comedy game show segment called "Square Celebrities", suspended by a wire to ask the "celebrities" questions. His next appearance was on the short-lived chat/comedy show ''One Hour with Jonathan Ross'' in a [[game show]] segment known as ''Knock Down Ginger''. Reeves' growing [[Television|TV]] profile led to ''[[Vic Reeves Big Night Out|Big Night Out]]'' being given a slot on [[Channel 4]] the following year. It was about this time that Reeves and Mortimer rented a back room at [[Jools Holland]]'s office/recording studio in [[Westcombe Park]], [[Greenwich]] where they would spend hours writing material. The name Reeves is due to his fondness of the late American singer [[Jim Reeves]]. Reeves continued to work alongside Mortimer as a comedy duo in ''[[The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer]]'', ''[[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]]'', and ''[[Bang Bang, It's Reeves and Mortimer]]'', some of which also featured future cast members of ''[[The Fast Show]]'' and ''[[Little Britain]]''. Reeves is one of the few comedians to have had a number one record in the [[UK Singles Chart]], which he did in company with [[The Wonder Stuff]], singing "[[Dizzy (Tommy Roe song)|Dizzy]]" (previously a number one hit for [[Tommy Roe]]). Including "Dizzy", he released two other singles from his 1991 album ''[[I Will Cure You]]''. A 1994 pilot written by [[Paul Whitehouse]] and [[Charlie Higson]] entitled ''The Honeymoon's Over'' was due to feature Chris Bell, a character from ''[[The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer]]''; however, the series was never commissioned. The same year, Reeves made a guest appearance on the Radio 1 series ''Shuttleworth's Showtime'', hosted by [[John Shuttleworth (character)|John Shuttleworth]]. Between August 1998 and May 1999, Reeves and Mortimer presented the [[Channel X]] produced [[BBC]] Saturday game show ''Families at War'' with [[Alice Beer]]. Reeves played [[Marty Hopkirk]] in the [[BBC]]'s 2000–2001 [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] series ''[[Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) (2000 TV series)|Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)]]'' – a revival of the [[Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)|original 1960s series]], with Mortimer as [[Jeff Randall|Randall]], [[Emilia Fox]] as [[Jeannie Hopkirk|Jeannie]] and [[Tom Baker]] as Wyvern. In 2000, Reeves presented a series entitled, ''Vic Reeves Examines'' on [[Play UK|UK Play]], featuring celebrities such as [[Ricky Gervais]], [[Johnny Vegas]], [[Lauren Laverne]] and [[Emma Kennedy]] discussing a topic of their choice. The same year, Reeves presented a one-off radio show on [[BBC Radio 1]], entitled ''Cock of the Wood''. In 2004 Reeves and Sorrell were both contestants in the fourth series of ''[[I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!]]''. He appeared in the series ''[[Catterick (TV series)|Catterick]]'' with mortimer appearing as several characters. In September 2005, Reeves hosted a show for [[Virgin Radio]] called ''Vic Reeves Big Night In'' produced by Mark Augustyn, for a short period on Wednesdays and Thursdays from 7.00pm. In May 2006, Reeves presented a programme on [[Tyne Tees Television|ITV Tyne Tees]] about Northeast comedy culture called ''It's Funny Up North with... Vic Reeves''. Reeves presented a historical ten-part series, entitled ''Rogues Gallery'', which was shown on the [[Discovery Channel]] (UK) in 2005, where he investigated, and portrayed [[Anne Bonny]] and [[Mary Read]], [[William Kidd|Captain Kidd]], [[Claude Duval]], [[Jonathan Wild]], [[Robert Roy MacGregor|Rob Roy]], [[Thomas Blood|Colonel Blood]], [[The Aldington Gang|George Ransley]], [[William Brodie|Deacon Brodie]], [[Blackbeard]] and [[Dick Turpin]]. Sorrell also appeared in some episodes. Continuing in this vein, ''Vic Reeves' Pirates'' was shown on [[ITV Wales & West|ITV West]] and, subsequently, on the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] in 2007. In 2007, Reeves hosted a show called ''Vic Reeves Investigates: [[Jack the Ripper]]''. Reeves, with the help of historians and leading experts, tried to discover who Jack the Ripper was. At the end of the show, he came to the conclusion that Jack the Ripper was [[Francis Tumblety]]. On 8 May 2007, Reeves was the main presenter of ''[[Brainiac: Science Abuse]]'' during the fifth and sixth series, replacing [[Richard Hammond]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/5345812.stm BBC: Vic Reeves to host Sky's Brainiac] Beginning in June 2007, Reeves presented a [[BBC Radio 2]] panel game called ''[[Does the Team Think?]]''. On 17 November 2007, Reeves appeared in a weekly sketch show on [[BBC Radio 2]], entitled ''[[Vic Reeves' House Arrest]]''. The show's premise was that Reeves had been put under [[house arrest]] for "a crime he didn't commit", and each episode consists of the various events that take place in and around his house on a particular day. Mortimer plays his housecall-making hairdresser, Carl, while other performers include ''[[The Mighty Boosh]]'' star [[Noel Fielding]] as a local vagrant who comes to Reeves' door on a weekly basis looking for work, as well as Sorrell in multiple roles.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/comedy/vicreeves.shtml BBC – Radio 2 Comedy – Vic Reeves' House Arrest] On 27 February 2008, Reeves announced that he and Mortimer were working together on a new sitcom about super heroes who get their powers through a malfunctioning telegraph pole.{{cite web | title=Journal Live | work=Reeves enjoys a Big Day Out with apprentices | url=http://www.journallive.co.uk/north-east-news/todays-news/2008/02/27/reeves-enjoys-a-big-day-out-with-apprentices-61634-20527947/ | accessdate=28 February 2008}} He also reiterated his desire to bring back ''[[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]]'' for a 6th series. Along with his son, Reeves is also featured in one edition of a factual series for [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]], ''Dangerous Adventures for Boys'', based on the best-selling book written by [[Conn Iggulden|Conn and Hal Iggulden]], ''[[The Dangerous Book for Boys]]''. In February 2009, Reeves appeared as presenter of the first episode of ''My Brilliant Britain'', one of the new television shows commissioned for [[UKTV People]] channel's relaunch as [[Blighty (TV channel)|Blighty]].{{cite web |title = Preview: My Brilliant Britain |work = Series preview |publisher = Sky |url = http://tv.sky.com/preview-my-brilliant-britain |accessdate = 17 May 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090221032549/http://tv.sky.com/preview-my-brilliant-britain |archivedate = 21 February 2009 |df = dmy-all }} On 25 August 2009, Reeves appeared as a guest on the [[BBC One]]'s ''[[The One Show]]'' with Mortimer. Series 6 of ''[[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]]'' began airing on 26 August 2009 with Reeves and Mortimer, along with [[Ulrika Jonsson]] and [[Jack Dee]] as team captains. Reeves appeared as one of the guests in ''[[Reece Shearsmith]]'s Haunted House'', a light-hearted radio discussion show broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] in two parts on either side of Halloween on 29 October 2009 and 5 November 2009.{{cite web | title=Reece Shearsmith's Haunted House – Production Details, Plus Regular Cast and Crew | work=Comedy Guide entry | publisher=The British Comedy Guide | url=http://www.comedy.org.uk/guide/radio/reece_shearsmith_haunted_house/details/ | accessdate=29 October 2009}} Reeves also lends his voice to the Virgin Atlantic Airlines onboard safety video, with [[Dani Behr]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KR4dxPISegY] Virgin Atlantic Safety Video In July 2011, Reeves and Mortimer for a selection of YouTube improvised comedy sketches, in association with [[Foster's Group|Foster's]]. They released their "Afternoon Delight" clips every weekday afternoon in July. ===Television appearances=== {{For|Reeves' television appearances with Bob Mortimer|Vic and Bob#Television}} Reeves has appeared without Mortimer on a number of British television shows, primarily [[game show]]s, poll programmes and charity [[telethon]]s. || ''[[British Comedy Awards 1993]]'' || [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] || |} ==Art== Alongside his comedy, Reeves is a serious artist, although the two often combine. Reeves works in many media including painting, ceramics, photography and lino prints, and has a distinctive style.{{cite web |url=http://www.eyestorm.com/Pages/Magazine.aspx/VIC_REEVES___%7C___NEW_LINO_CUT_PRINTS/373 |title=Vic Reeves' lino cut prints}} His work has been described as [[Dada]]-esque, surreal and sometimes macabre. For Reeves, his art and comedy are different ways of expressing the same idea. He says "I think putting your imagination on canvas or a television screen is the same thing"{{cite web |url=https://thestrandgallery.wordpress.com/2013/02/05/coming-up-hot-valve-leak-visual-ramblings-of-vic-reeves |title=Hot Valve Leak at the Strand Gallery}} and "I don't differentiate between painting, acting or comedy. I think everything I do is art."{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-13060135 |title=Vic Reeves puts 250 artworks on sale}} Reeves has stated that he is an artist first and a comedian second, and that in ten years time he would like to be remembered for his art and writing, rather than his comedy. Much like his comedy, Reeves is not one to analyse his artworks. He has said that art should be "just for laughs" and that he dislikes people looking for statements in his work, because there are none. "If something makes me laugh, that's it."{{cite web|last1=Burkeman|first1=Oliver|title=Having a laugh|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2000/sep/28/artsfeatures3|accessdate=3 February 2015}} "I've done straight drawings and paintings ... and I haven't got as much pleasure out of them as if I'd done something that would make me laugh."{{cite web|last1=Leo|first1=Benedictus|title=When something goes down the pan, enjoy it|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2006/jun/05/biography.comedy|accessdate=3 February 2015}} His work has been described by artists [[Jake and Dinos Chapman]] as "able to command our laughter as a purgative, to encourage the viewer to leak at both ends".{{cite web|last1=Baker|first1=Lindsay|title=Call Me Dada|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2002/jun/22/artsfeatures.features2|accessdate=3 February 2015}} Artist [[Damien Hirst]], a friend of Reeves', has also described Reeves as an influence.{{cite book|last1=Thompson|first1=Ben|title=Sunshine On Putty|date=2004|publisher=Harper Perennial|location=London|isbn=0 00 718132 9|page=254}}{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruce|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Media|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=162}} This crossover of comedy and art often features within Reeves and Mortimer's television shows. A notable example is ''[[The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer]]'''s first episode. Several of Reeves' drawings are featured, illustrating the lyrics of the opening song. (These drawings would later be published within his book ''Sun Boiled Onions''.) As seen in the script book for the show, Reeves often drew sketches for the BBC's costume and set designers saying that "if we just tell them what we want, it never ends up looking like it does in our minds". ===Background and education=== Arts and crafts played a large part in Reeves' upbringing. His mother and father, a [[seamstress]] and [[typesetting|typesetter]] by trade, made extra money by selling handmade wooden crafts and [[Ceramic art|ceramics]] at local markets.{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Vic|title=Me: Moir|date=2006|publisher=Virgin|location=London|isbn=1-85227-350-X |pages=171–172}} Building on these money-making schemes, Reeves began charging for his own artistic services such as customising and painting his school friend's [[Haversack]] bags{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Vic|title=Me: Moir|date=2006|publisher=Virgin|location=London|isbn=1-85227-350-X |pages=133–134}} and elaborately [[Embroidery|embroidering]] clothing. Later he would go on to [[Art forgery|forge]] artworks his acquaintances liked with the aim of selling them to them. Wanting to study art, but being pressured into work, Reeves began a five-year [[engineering]] [[apprenticeship]] at a factory in [[Newton Aycliffe]] with the aim of working in their technical drawings department.{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Vic|title=Me: Moir|date=2006|publisher=Virgin|location=London|isbn=1-85227-350-X |pages=213–214}} After completing the apprenticeship, Reeves applied to [[Goldsmith's College]] in London to study art, but failed to get a place. He has admitted to sneaking in and using their equipment regardless.{{cite book|last1=Thompson|first1=Ben|title=Sunshine On Putty|date=2004|publisher=Harper Perennial|location=London|isbn=0 00 718132 9|page=253}} In 1983 he completed a one-year foundation course at [[Sir John Cass College]], where he is now an honorary graduate.{{cite web|title=Hot Valve Leak|url=http://www.thecass.com/news-events/2013/february/hot-valve-leak|accessdate=3 February 2015}} Once leaving college, he worked as a curator at The Garden Gallery, an independent London gallery. It was there that he held his first art exhibition in 1985, with the help of a grant from [[Lewisham]] Council.{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruce|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Media|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|pages=31–32}} ===Published work and exhibitions=== Reeves has released two books of his art, ''Sun Boiled Onions'' in 1999 and ''Vic Reeves' Vast Book of World Knowledge'' in 2009. His drawings also appear in his autobiography ''Me:Moir Volume One'', and the published script book for ''The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer''.{{cite book|title=The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer|date=1993|publisher=Fantail Books|location=London|isbn=0-14-090012--8}}{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Vic|title=Me: Moir|date=2006|publisher=Virgin|location=London|isbn=1-85227-350-X}} He provided thirty illustrations for [[Random House]]'s 2011 reprint of [[Jerome K. Jerome]]'s classic story "Three Men in a Boat".{{cite book|last1=Jerome|first1=Jerome K.|title=Three men in a boat: to say nothing of the dog!|date=2011|publisher=Vintage Books|location=London|isbn=9780099511700}} He was also commissioned to create several celebrity drawings for [[Jools Holland]]'s [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]] series "Name That Tune".{{cite journal|last1=Ben|first1=Thompson|title=Viva! Las Degas|journal=GQ|date=December 1997|page=216}} Reeves has hosted several exhibitions of his artwork, including: *''Sun Boiled Onions'' (2000) at the Percy Miller Gallery *''Doings'' (2002) at the [[Whitechapel Gallery]], London{{cite web|last1=Walsh|first1=John|title=Funny peculiar: The curious world of Vic Reeves|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-peculiar-the-curious-world-of-vic-reeves-1792545.html|accessdate=3 February 2015}} *''My Family and Other Freaks'' (2007) at the Eyestorm Gallery, London{{cite web|title=Vic Reeves artist biography|url=http://www.eyestorm.com/Pages/Product.aspx/Vic_Reeves/Crested_Tit/4580331|accessdate=3 February 2015}} *''Where Eagles Tremble'' (2009) at Mews of Mayfair, London{{cite web|url=http://www.mewsofmayfair.com/site/press/releases/press_release13.asp |accessdate=3 February 2015 |title=Where Eagles Tremble press release}} *''Hot Valve Leak: Visual Ramblings of Vic Reeves'' (2013) at the Strand Gallery, London In 2010, a selection of Reeves' paintings were displayed at the [[Saatchi Gallery]], London as part of an exhibition by charity The Art of Giving. He was also a judge for the charity's open art competition.{{cite web|title=The Art of Giving: Vic Reeves|url=http://www.artofgiving.co.uk/artists/r/vic-reeves/|accessdate=3 February 2015}} In 2012, Reeves took part in the Illuminating York festival. His illuminations, known as "Wonderland", were projected across a number of historic buildings including the [[Yorkshire Museum]], [[St Mary's Abbey, York|St Mary's Abbey]], and the ten-acre site of [[York Museum Gardens]].{{cite web|title=Illuminating York 2012|url=http://illuminatingyork.org.uk/the-main-events-2/kippa-matthews-copyright-notice-4|accessdate=3 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204053554/http://illuminatingyork.org.uk/the-main-events-2/kippa-matthews-copyright-notice-4/|archivedate=4 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last1=Rychlikova|first1=Megi|title=Illuminating York set to launch Vic Reeves’ surreal wonderland|url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/10017372.Illuminating_York_set_to_launch_Vic_Reeves____surreal_wonderland/|accessdate=3 February 2015}} ==Music== Before finding fame with his comedy, Reeves was a member of several bands with many different names and musical styles, in which he usually played bass guitar and/or sang.{{cite book|last1=Reeves|first1=Vic|title=Me:Moir Volume One|date=2006|publisher=Virgin Books|location=London|isbn=1 8522 7350 X|page=205}} He sold tapes of his early material in the back pages of [[NME]] magazine under the name "International Cod".{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=Neil|title=Document and Eyewitness: An Intimate History of Rough Trade|date=2010|publisher=Orion Publishing|isbn=978-1-4091-1221-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lqQbgGhFCr8C|accessdate=16 January 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruse|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=21}} [[Mark Lamarr]], later to become team captain of [[Shooting Stars (TV series)|Shooting Stars]], was sent an early tape of Reeves’ band "Fantantiddlyspan",{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruce|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=29}} whose song "Fantasia" was played on ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' by Lamarr in 1998, in an attempt to embarrass him.{{Cite episode |title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gbCALj4gsY8 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |series=4 |number=1 |date=11 September 1998 |network=[[BBC Two]]}} As part of early [[Vic Reeves Big Night Out|''Big Night Out'']] performances, Reeves would sometimes hand out promotional materials to the audience. On one occasion he handed out a 7" [[flexi disc]] of original song "The Howlin’ Wind".{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruse|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=66}} Having surplus copies of the discs, Reeves passed them on to [[Darlington]]-based band Dan who then included a copy of the disc with their album ''Kicking Ass at T.J.'s''.{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruse|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|pages=103–104}}{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Dan-Kicking-Ass-At-TJs/release/1160627 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Dan album, Kicking Ass at T.J.'s}} ===Album=== ''[[I Will Cure You]]'' was Reeves' only album. It was released in 1991 by [[Island Records]] and peaked at No. 16 in the [[UK Albums Chart]]. It featured the Number One single "[[Dizzy (Tommy Roe song)|Dizzy]]" which was a collaboration with [[The Wonder Stuff]].[http://www.discogs.com/Vic-Reeves-I-Will-Cure-You/release/1787467 Discogs] It included a mixture of covers and original songs in a variety of musical styles, many of which were originally introduced in [[Vic Reeves Big Night Out|''Big Night Out'']]. Along with "Dizzy", two other singles were released from the album, a cover of the [[Matt Monro]] song "[[Born Free (Matt Monro song)|Born Free]]" and a dance reworking of [[Christian]] [[hymn]] "[[Abide With Me]]" which reached No. 6 and No. 47 in the [[UK Singles Chart]] respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/search-results-album/_/born+free |title=Born Free chart position |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202021942/http://www.officialcharts.com/search-results-album/_/born+free |archivedate=2 February 2015 }} ===Singles=== {{For|singles released from ''I Will Cure You''|I Will Cure You#Singles}} In 1995, Reeves and Mortimer released a cover of [[The Monkees]] song "[[I'm a Believer]]" with British band [[EMF (band)|EMF]] which reached No. 3 in the [[UK Singles Chart]].{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/emf/reeves%20%26%20mortimer/ |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Official charts, I'm a Believer}} Reeves had a history with the track, having both sung it at the beginning of early ''[[Vic Reeves Big Night Out|Big Night Out]]'' performances in London, and opened the [[Channel 4]] series with it.{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruse|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=152}} In the music video, which was directed by Reeves,{{cite web |url=http://www.mvdbase.com/video.php?id=9686 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=I'm A Believer, cast and crew}} the duo dress as [[Michael Nesmith|Mike Nesmith]] and [[Davy Jones (musician)|Davy Jones]] of The Monkees.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9un6gdY8-Fk |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Music video: I'm A Believer}} On the CD release of the single, a studio version of "At This Stage I Couldn't Say" was included, a track originally sung by characters Mulligan and O’Hare in ''[[The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/EMF-Reeves-Mortimer-Im-A-Believer/release/2371678 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Discogs: I'm A Believer CD}} On the 7" release, the bonus track was "At Least We’ve Got Our Guitars", which was the opening song for the last episode of ''The Smell of Reeves and Mortimer''.{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/EMF-Reeves-Mortimer-Im-A-Believer/release/3175318 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Discogs: I'm A Believer 7}} In April 2007, the theme to British stop-motion animation ''[[Shaun the Sheep]]'', sung by Reeves, was released as a single.{{cite news|last1=Walters|first1=Sarah|title=Shaun The Sheep Ft Vic Reeves - Life's A Treat (Tug)|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/shaun-the-sheep-ft-vic-reeves-1013359|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=Manchester Evening News|date=7 December 2007}} The song reached No. 20 in the UK Singles Chart.{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/_/shaun%20the%20sheep |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=UK Singles Chart, Shaun the Sheep theme}} ===Contributions=== In 1990 both Reeves and Mortimer contributed backing vocals to [[Jools Holland]]'s "Holy Cow" (a [[Lee Dorsey]] cover). The track was included on Holland's album ''World of his Own'' and also released as a single.{{cite book|last1=Dessau|first1=Bruse|title=Reeves & Mortimer|date=1998|publisher=Orion Books|location=London|isbn=0-75281-781-7|page=103}}{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Jools-Holland-Holy-Cow/release/4619700 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Discogs, Holy Cow}} Later, Reeves would advertise Holland's album ''Moving Out to the Country''.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l7X6FCiazhw |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Advert, Moving Out to the Country}} Also in 1990, Reeves provided backing vocals for former [[The Smiths|Smiths]] singer [[Morrissey]]'s cover of "[[That's Entertainment (The Jam song)|That's Entertainment]]", originally by [[The Jam]].{{cite journal|last1=Maconie|first1=Stuart|title=Why does this man want to be a popstar?|journal=NME|date=6 April 1991|page=50}} Reeves' vocals were not used in the final edit but he was thanked (as Jim Moir) in the sleeve notes of Morrissey's [[Sing Your Life]] single, which featured "That's Entertainment" as a bonus track.{{cite book|last1=Goddard|first1=Simon|title=Mozipedia: The Encyclopaedia of Morrissey and the Smiths|date=2009|publisher=Ebury Publishing|pages=347–8}}{{Cite AV media notes |title=Morrissey, Sing Your Life credits |year=1990 |type=CD sleeve notes |publisher=A and Son Music Ltd. |url=http://www.discogs.com/Morrissey-Sing-Your-Life/release/396936}} A fan of the Smiths, Reeves opened some episodes of [[Vic Reeves Big Night Out|''Big Night Out'']] with covers of the band's songs including "[[Sheila Take a Bow]]" which he intended to include a cover of on his album ''[[I Will Cure You]]''. It did not make the final cut. In 1992, Reeves contributed a track to ''[[Ruby Trax]]'', a compilation album released by ''[[NME]]'' magazine to commemorate 40 years of the publication. He covered the [[Ultravox]] song "[[Vienna (Ultravox song)|Vienna]]", but drastically altered the original lyrics.{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-Ruby-Trax-The-NMEs-Roaring-Forty/master/25429 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Discogs: NME's Ruby Trax}} In 1998, Reeves contributed to ''[[Twentieth-Century Blues: The Songs of Noel Coward]]'', a tribute album featuring notable singers and bands such as [[Elton John]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Robbie Williams]] and [[Paul McCartney]]. Reeves covered Coward's 1934 track "Don’t Put Your Daughter on the Stage Mrs. Worthington", which was arranged by [[David Arnold]] for the album. The song, described by Reeves as "sinister",{{cite journal|last1=Dalton|first1=Stephen|title=Carry On Camping|journal=NME|date=18 April 1998|page=37}} was initially recorded with all original verses intact, but as the last included foul language, it was edited out of the final release. In 2000, Reeves’ cover of "[[Ain't That a Kick in the Head?]]" was featured as a bonus track on the theme single to the [[Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) (2000 TV series)|''Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)'']] series in which he starred. Reeves was originally to duet with [[Nina Persson]] (of [[the Cardigans]]), who provided vocals, but missed the final cut.{{cite book|last1=Lane|first1=Andy|title=Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased): the files|date=2001|publisher=Boxtree|location=London|isbn=0-7522-2356-9|page=115}} A shortened version of Reeves' cover also featured in the series itself.{{Cite episode |title=Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kj7EmxLNODc |accessdate=16 January 2015 |series=1 |number=5 |date=15 April 2000 |network=[[BBC One]]}} Both Reeves and Mortimer appeared in the music video for the single. ===Music videos=== {{For|music videos from I Will Cure You|I Will Cure You#Music videos}} Other than the music videos for his own singles, Reeves has appeared in others. His first was the 1987 video for [[Shakin' Stevens]]’ single "What Do You Want to Make Those Eyes at Me For".{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/music/sites/shakin-stevens/pages/collection.shtml |title=BBC Wales – Music – Shakin' Stevens – The Collection |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=23 April 2012}} He was hired for the shoot and paid £10 for his appearance.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VhBdxUq6j28 |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Shakin' Stevens, What Do You... music video}} Reeves also appeared in the 1988 music video for [[Band of Holy Joy]]'s song "Tactless". He introduces the band and can be seen at the bar part way through. The video was filmed in Deptford, London and original advertising posters for ''Big Night Out'' can be seen at the beginning.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WLPSaeXNKmY |accessdate=16 January 2015 |title=Band of Holy Joy, Tactless music video}} ==Books== {{For|books on or by Reeves and Mortimer|Vic and Bob#Books}} * ''Vic Reeves' Vast Book of World Knowledge'' – a surreal encyclopaedia with text and artwork by Reeves. [[Grove/Atlantic, Inc.|Atlantic Books]], Released in October 2009.{{cite web |title = Atlantic buys Vic Reeves' nous |work = News story |url = http://www.thebookseller.com/news/76657-atlantic-buys-vic-reeves-nous.html |accessdate = 16 April 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090722010404/http://www.thebookseller.com/news/76657-atlantic-buys-vic-reeves-nous.html |archivedate = 22 July 2009 |df = dmy-all }} * ''Vic Reeves Me:Moir (Volume One)'' – autobiography by Vic Reeves, [[Virgin Books]], 2006 * ''Sunboiled Onions'' – diary, paintings and drawings by Vic Reeves, [[Penguin Books]], 1999 ==Advertising== {{For|advertisements featuring both Reeves and Mortimer|Vic and Bob#Advertising}} Reeves has appeared in television advertisements for a number of products, both with Mortimer and alone. * An advertisement for [[Guinness]] quoted Reeves as saying "88.2% of statistics are made up on the spot" * Reeves has done solo advertising work for a variety of products including [[MFI Group|MFI]], [[Müller Light]], [[First Direct]], Churchill Insurance, Cadbury's Boost, [[Mars Bar]], [[Fanta]], [[H. J. Heinz Company|Heinz]] [[Ketchup|Tomato Ketchup]], [[Domestos]] bleach, [[Maryland Cookies]] and he cross-dressed for a 2008 advertisement for [[888 Holdings]]' Bingo website [[888 Holdings#888ladies|888 Ladies]]. * Reeves also advertised [[Jools Holland]]'s 2006 album ''Moving Out to the Country''. *In 2011, Reeves was featured in an [[East Coast (train operating company)|East Coast Trains]] television advertisement, promoting the first class service. During the advert, he is seen using his love of art by sketching and painting the surrounding passengers and on-board train attendant. Reeves also featured in a 2012 radio advert for the company. ==Personal life== Reeves was born in [[Leeds]], the son of James Neill (1926–2004) and Audrey Moir (née Leigh). At the age of five, he moved to [[Darlington]], [[County Durham]], with his parents and younger sister Lois. He attended Heathfield Infants and Junior School and went on to the nearby secondary school, [[Eastbourne Church of England Academy|Eastbourne Comprehensive]] in [[Darlington]]. Reeves has four children, the eldest two by his first wife Sarah Vincent, whom he married in 1990 and divorced in 1999. He met his second wife, [[Nancy Sorrell]], in 2001, and the couple married on 25 January 2003. Sorrell gave birth to twin girls Beth and Nell at the [[William Harvey Hospital]] in [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]], [[Kent]], on 25 May 2006. Reeves lives in [[Charing]], near Ashford.{{cite news|title=Vic Reeves puts 250 artworks on sale|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-kent-13060135|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=13 April 2011|accessdate=13 September 2011}} He buried his [[classic car|classic]] [[Austin A40 Somerset]] in his back garden, as shown on the [[BBC]]'s 1997 ''[[Omnibus (UK TV series)|Omnibus]]'' documentary "A Film Of Reeves & Mortimer". ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.skyone.co.uk/jacktheripper/ Sky one Webpage about Vic Reeves Investigates: Jack the Ripper] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230108/http://www.thehistorychannel.co.uk/site/tv_guide/full_details/World_history/programme_56.php Vic Reeves Pirates] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/kent/4467757.stm Driving Ban For Comic Vic Reeves]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090916091824/http://www.convilleandwalsh.com/index.php/authors/author/vic-reeves/ Vic Reeves' author page], [[Conville and Walsh]]. * [Fantazia by Fan Tan Tidly Span Side A available on YouTube but link blocked here] * [Fantazia by Fan Tan Tidly Span Side B available on YouTube but link blocked here] {{Vic and Bob}} {{Absolute Radio|state=autocollapse}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reeves, Vic}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Leeds]] [[Category:People from Darlington]] [[Category:Alumni of Middlesex University]] [[Category:Comedians from Yorkshire]] [[Category:English radio personalities]] [[Category:English television presenters]] [[Category:English male comedians]] [[Category:English autobiographers]] [[Category:English comedy musicians]] [[Category:English male television actors]] [[Category:English radio DJs]] [[Category:Virgin Radio (UK)]] [[Category:English comedy writers]] [[Category:Surrealist artists]]
